Author Info: Verified User Current Employee F***** IOS Software Engineer - Apr 16, 2022

Pros: Compensation for an entry-level employee fresh out of college or certificate programs is not bad, it's a good starting point.Work-Life balance is pretty good. I'm not working nights or weekends so that's great, and I sign off at a decent hour.Company Culture: People are nice, friendly, and are absolutely willing to help if you have questions (some people you learn to not bother so much, but that's with any company). There are Slack channels for your interests. Career Growth is meh. There are plenty of opportunities to learn and strengthen your skills.
Cons: It's definitely a stepping stone sort of place for entry-level hires. I can see why many leave after 2 years at least or 4 years at most. (If you feel like you're not learning anything after 1-2 years, leave. Years of experience mean little if you don't have any projects or skills to show for it.)Compensation: it's a good starting point for entry-level positions, but compensation can take a long time to grow with you if you're planning to stay for 3-5+ years. Company Culture: Teams/Departments tend to be siloed. If you're someone that values more personal project hand-offs, who likes to get to know their colleagues a little bit, it's achievable to do that but the environment can get a bit solitary and echo-ey at times.Career Growth: while *learning* opportunities are available and in decent amounts, being promoted into higher-level positions or getting promoted into having a higher salary, is actually quite difficult to achieve. It's dismal. I've met individuals who have been with IBM for 2 decades and only are just beginning to break into higher-level positions.Lay-offs are prevalent at times. It's not uncommon to have a lay-off season. In a similar vein, there's a significant turnover rate. (again, that depends on your department). Someone on the team may decide to leave within the year or just after a year of your arrival, thus increasing the workload for some people, which causes them to leave because the workload is too much, which puts more work onto more people and they leave, and that puts more work... you get the idea. It's a vicious cycle.

Description: Totally depends on management chain and client
Pros: Rating IBM is like the story of the blind men and the elephant: what it's like depends almost completely on your first and second level up line managers, combined with whatever your primary client is (assuming you're primarily billable and not part of an internal R&D or development team). Where I am, I'd say it's pretty good. I've got a steady client, I don't have to spend a lot of time and energy finding work/projects, and management knows how valuable the skills of my small team are.
Cons: Despite a lot of positive spin, and an ongoing attempt to reinvent itself (again) as a cloud analytics and hybrid cloud provider, IBM still feels like a sinking ship sometimes. Too much middle management, trying to do too many things at once, and the more than occasional short-sighted decisions make it challenging to defend being there. Combine that with meager annual increases and benefits that get expensive quickly when you have more than one child to cover, and the cons start to loom. Other times, like when I hear news about the 100-qubit quantum computer just released, and see proactive, progressive policies for equality of all kinds, a clear and firm code of ethics, and active encouragement for reporting of unfair/unequal/unethical behavior, I'm proud to be an IBMer.

Author Info: Verified User Current Employee X***** Finance Manager Team Lead - Oct 12, 2021

Pros: I've worked for IBM for over 5 years and I've learned a lot over that time—through sponsored external education and testing methods from books in my day to day work. This can be a great place to learn and grow your career with the right mentors and managers, but you own your career here—no one else. Expect to read books, take classes to help set the strategy for a 100+ year company to pivot into the age of cloud computing and AI. That's what you were hired for. If you enjoy navigating ambiguity and setting strategies, this can be an interesting place to work. Unlike some other companies, you can log off at 5pm and no one is going to fault you for enjoying your life.
Cons: It's a large corporate company with a ton of bureaucracy. It can take an unnecessarily long time to do common sense things, largely because too many people don't understand digital marketing or marketing data. That lack of expertise can be incredibly frustrating when you have that expertise…but it's also an opportunity to practice communication skills and educate a workforce towards a common goal. With all that said, this has improved over the years but we still need to make more progress here.Culture can be a huge problem here depending on your team. I've been on toxic teams which will try to destroy your self esteem, but I've also been on empowering teams which encourage you to take more risks. Aligning yourself to the right teams will be critical to your success at this company. Additionally while the company is restructuring (at a massive scale) to help eliminate silos, it'll be interesting how the culture evolves with a smaller marketing workforce. Historically, team goals have been largely unaligned to other adjacent teams, making it challenging to achieve business outcomes. However, if goals are more aligned given the unification of teams across marketing, then the company could potentially make a lot of progress on business outcomes in the future. Remains to be seen.

Pros: - Great work life balance. No hard push. Infrequent deadline.- Very flexible management. I'm not in a remote position, but management is generally flexible if you have anything and want to work remotely on that day.- Free Udemy business. Very helpful in building skills.- Excellent 401k plan. This is one of the the best 401k plans among tech companies I've seen for investment geeks who value the advantages of tax-advantaged investment accounts. - Match up to 6% of the base (by contributing 5% of your base). This is further enhanced due to the fact that IBM doesn't generally award bonus --- the base is usually 20% higher than other big corps in the area. This results in more company match than Google (also arguably the best 401k plan) if you contribute no less than 5% of your base for mid-level positions. - Employees can contribute to 10% after-tax. - The investment choices are well structured. All core investments for a basic portfolio are available at low cost, plus many low-cost extended choices, such as Dimensional Fund Advisor (DFA) funds.
Cons: - Total compensation is generally not as good as other big corps.- Company work pace is slow. The good aspect is that everyone is slow, the bad aspect is that... everything you request others is slow as well.- The pace is slow, again. This means that career growth may be more difficult than elsewhere. If you need to learn from work, this is not a good place. But if you are confident in your skills and can manage to do some influential side projects, this can be turned to an advantage (Company projects, which are often shitty, won't bother you too much).
